item.title: Keynote - Emma Jane Westby - Drupal Superstar
item.description:
Friday 22nd, 10:00
Presenter: 
emmajane

This is hard to type as we're soooooo excited. Our keynote speaker this year is going to be EMMA JANE WESTBY!!!

 

Emma is going to talk about:

Managing Projects the Drupal Way
You're organised, you love spreadsheets, you're a great cheerleader, you handle a backlog with superhero skills, and now you're faced with managing a Drupal project and everything just feels foreign. It's not you, it's Drupal. The mix of site building, front end development, backend development, and over 20,000 contributed modules makes project management for Drupal exceptionally frustrating for people who've not worked with Drupal before.

This session will cover:

- the basic Drupal development workflow (from a developer's perspective, but without using developer jargon)
writing useful tickets which developers can accomplish
- estimation tips for multi-discipline tickets (design / back end / front end)
- ideal team structures -- and what to do if you can't get them

Bring your questions, and bring your experience -- plenty of time will be left for discussion at the end of the session.

slides:
https://speakerdeck.com/emmajane/managing-projects-the-drupal-way-in-ireland

slides with notes:
http://www.slideshare.net/emmajane/managing-a-project-the-drupal-way

Slides
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

If you are getting started with Drupal and feeling a bit over-whelmed by all the different ways you can do things, then this session is for you.

Here, Fearghal O'Kane from BT48 will discuss the modules he uses to most effect when building Drupal websites.

item.title: Drupal as a publishing platform for podcasts
item.description:
Friday 22nd, 11:30
Presenter: 
conor
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development

Drupal is a great content management framework for building an online media publishing platform. And usually it just requires another contributed module to add extra functionality. 

Very successful shows like Serial Podcast from the makers of This American Life, chose to build their website with Drupal 7. But there isn’t one tried and tested turn-key module for publishing podcasts, that then work well out of the box, with podcast aggregators like Apple iTunes.

This presentation will look at one essential module that can be the keystone for building and configuring a podcasting platform.

Some alternative platforms will be compared and one hybrid combination will be shared.

This presentation is aimed at publishers. No prior knowledge of Drupal is required.

Update

Thank you to everyone that came to the Drupal Open Days 2015, especially to everyone that asked questions and offered insights. Below are links from this presentation, with some additional links following from questions during and after it. Hope these links help, please ensure that that any app or module is suitable before installing on your system.

item.dc:creator: conor

item.title: Drupal, I love you, but you're bringing me down
item.description:
Friday 22nd, 12:15
Presenter: 
gary.hammond
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

I have worked with Drupal, wearing many hats since 2007. That equates to the entirety of my professional career since finishing college. In my previous job I worked with the CMS full time doing front end development, configuration, coding, system architecture, infrastructure, deployments and support. I started out working with Drupal 5 and over four years learned to love it from a development perspective. Four years later I moved on and founded iterate.

I am no longer a developer, I haven't built anything with Drupal in two years and never will again. My current role though still involves Drupal, a lot. We advocate and propose the vast majority of web solutions on the platform. Drupal has been the CMS we have used at iterate since we began and remains to be. It has helped us establish ourselves and scale while securing high profile customers working on enjoyable and rewarding projects. I do not envisage a time where Drupal will not be a significant part of the toolkit used by our development team.

My own perspective on Drupal is however different now as I work with it in a different role. This talk will cover some of the obstacles faced by both agency and customer and how they can be overcome. It will also discuss some of the ways Drupal is, has been and will likely continue to be which while may be great for developers may hinder wider adoption of the platform.

Slides
item.dc:creator: gary.hammond

item.title: About the GEC
item.description:

This is a brief talk from our sponsors and venue providers The Guinnesss Enterprise Centre to introduce the great work that they do.
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

item.title: Why so sketchy? An introduction to sketching
item.description:
Friday 22nd, 13:45
Room: 
Meeting Room 1
Presenter: 
renreilly
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Design

User Experience Design is a balancing act between user requirements, business needs and technical constraints. Why then, do so many companies only involve their developers in the final stage of their projects? Involving your developers in the UX process from the beginning means they will understand the rationale for the website and the design approach. They are an invaluable source of information and will provide valuable inputs and contributions, which in turn will mean better design decisions.

In this hands-on workshop, you will learn about and practice the iterative approach of sketching with pen and paper (controversial). Sketches are quick visual representations of ideas that may lead to solutions. It's a collaborative technique, which should involve your whole project team. Sketching is not an art and everyone can do it so get onboard with this workshop to improve your Drupal websites. 

Thank you to everyone who attended the workshop - we had great fun! You can download the slides from the workshop here. Keep practicing!
item.dc:creator: renreilly

item.title: The Football Association of Ireland's Drupal & UEFA API Experience
item.description:
Friday 22nd, 13:45
Presenter: 
daniel.walsh
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development

Last year the FAI embarked on a journey to create a new online experience for Irish football fans. With Drupal the framework of choice, the challenges ranged from how best to meet the needs of all stakeholders in the football family, to how to create a rich multimedia and responsive experience for users. Match statistics were crucial to the project; the key technical and architectural hurdle was how best to integrate with UEFA's complex API's to deliver real time coverage of games in a Live Match Centre.

Peter Sherrard, FAI Communications Director will present the football perspective on the website build while Daniel Walsh, Developer will present the technical challenges the project posed and how they were overcome to deliver a best in class solution.
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

item.title: Doing the post-launch dance - the Art and science of successful support
item.description:
Friday 22nd, 14:30
Presenter: 
alanburke
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

You got the project live. It was on time. It was under budget. You did the post-launch dance. Then ...

... it's time to move to the support contract, because that great client wants some more great features (and that thing you thought was working, no longer is).

Here's the art and science of successful support.
item.dc:creator: alanburke

item.description:

Mark Conroy

General Web Development

You know the way you design a beautiful website, but the back end edit page is long, and ugly, and hard to follow, and ....

Well, let's fix this mess so that website users and content editors both have a lovely experience.

item.title: Drupal Open Q&A
item.description:
Friday 22nd, 16:00
Presenter: 
Mark Conroy
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

This is an open table discussion about Drupal, with a panel of the best of Ireland's Drupal talent. Basically, if you:

  • are wondering about adopting Drupal, but haven't made up your mind;
  • have a Drupal website, but have some issues with it;
  • are weighing up the pros and cons of open source versus proprietary software;
  • are concerned about the Drupal "learning cliff";
  • are investigating hosting solutions for Drupal;

then, come along, pitch your question, and get some answers.
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

See map for exact location. Those of you at last year's Open Days should be familiar with it already :)

Finger food with be provided, and for those making a night of it, there is live music later on.

item.title: Bridging the gap between business and technology - Behaviour Driven Development with Drupal
item.description:
Saturday 23rd, 10:00
Presenter: 
Marcin Pajdzik
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
Business & Strategy

A talk about how software development could be managed by both business interests and technical insights. It will present the best practices and software tools to support the development process in Drupal. The speaker will explain why and when a business may want to consider using Behaviour Driven Development and will show the advantages of using BDD from the perspective of both business stakeholders and developers.

Slides
item.dc:creator: Marcin Pajdzik

item.title: Local Development Environments
item.description:
Saturday 23rd, 10:45
Presenter: 
luisrc7
Session Level: 
Beginner
Session Theme: 
General Web Development

In this talk you will learn, in a couple of different ways, how to set up your first local development environment in you computer to start using your favourite CMS and playing around with Drupal. I will mention other approaches such as virtualisation, but we will focus this session in the basic configuration and installation of a working environment.

It will also include some of the useful tools I use on daily basis to complete your development environment like drush, git or sass.

At the end of this talk you will have learned how to install a local web server and have a couple of tools available to use for your development.

Slides
item.dc:creator: luisrc7

item.title: Break for Tea & Coffee
item.description:
Saturday 23rd, 11:25
Presenter: 
Mark Conroy
item.dc:creator: Mark Conroy

item.title: Building a RedHen CRM in your Drupal website
item.description:
Saturday 23rd, 11:45
Presenter: 
stella
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development

I bet you've heard of SalesForce, and Microsoft Dynamics, CiviCRM, and a whole host of other CRM systems that can plug into your Drupal website?

Yes? Well, have you ever thought of building a CRM within your Drupal website, using Drupal contributed modules, entities, and fields? It's a great solution for small to medium enterprises that want to keep control of all of their data and can't afford the price of commercial CRMs.

In this presentation, I'll walk you through the steps needed to create a CRM using Drupal 7 and RedHen.
item.dc:creator: stella

item.title: Less setup, more development: Drupal and Docker containers
item.description:
Saturday 23rd, 12:30
Presenter: 
geewiz
Session Level: 
Intermediate
Session Theme: 
Drupal Development

 

You've got a new Drupal project. But before you can even start working on the website, you need to set up your development environment. Pull the code, grab the database, configure a local web server, yada yada yada...

At Drupal Open Days Dublin back in 2013, I presented our solution to avoid this unproductive busy work: a VM containing a miniature version of our freistilbox hosting environment. With its rather big VM image, a long provisioning process and low content delivery performance, it was far from perfect.

Two years later, there's Docker. This tool for creating und running Linux containers has been around for a while now and has become a favourite of both developers and venture capitalists alike. Docker makes it easy for you to manage Linux containers, which are compute units that are much more lightweight than full virtual machines. You can spin up a Linux container from a pre-built image within seconds. Preparing such an image is easy, and thanks to a cleverly layered file system, images can even be built on top of each other.

In my talk, I'll highlight the most important features of Docker and demonstrate how you can use it to create an amazingly efficient environment for Drupal development.

Update: Here are the slides of my talk
item.dc:creator: geewiz
